description:
Geosmithia morbida is a fungal species that belongs to the genus Geosmithia. It is primarily known as the causal agent of thousand cankers disease, a devastating disease that affects various species of walnut trees (Juglans spp.).

Geosmithia morbida is a slow-growing, asexual fungus that produces small, greenish-gray to white colonies on culture media. The fungus produces conidiophores, which are specialized structures that give rise to the asexual spores called conidia. These conidia are the primary means of dispersal and infection for the fungus.

The fungus is transmitted by the walnut twig beetle (Pityophthorus juglandis), which acts as a vector, carrying the fungal spores from infected trees to healthy ones. The fungus colonizes the inner bark and cambium of the tree, leading to the formation of numerous small, dark cankers that can coalesce and ultimately girdle the tree, causing its death.

Geosmithia morbida is considered an invasive species in many regions where it has been introduced, as it poses a significant threat to the health and survival of valuable walnut tree populations. Understanding the biology and ecology of this fungus is crucial for developing effective management strategies to mitigate the impact of thousand cankers disease on walnut trees.
